text:
"it just sounds similar to when you play a nes on a crt"

Not really, no.
author: TheAverageGuyTAG

text: What are you talking about?  This is a song that came from Mega Man 9, a game that was designed to replicate an NES game.  The song is one that CAN be played on an NES.  And I'm not sure what you're trying to get at with the whole "emulators in max quality".  My point is, the lower the quality, the less it sounds like the original song.
author: TheAverageGuyTAG

text: That's not how it works though.  When you downgrade sound audio, it just makes it sound less like how it was originally uploaded.  Downgrading the sound quality of an mp3 file for an NES song doesn't make it sound more like an NES song, it just makes the song itself sound crappier.  You want to keep it as high-quality as possible to preserve the song as best as possible.
author: TheAverageGuyTAG

text: @Duorsa The graphical engine is 8 bits, which means it's, yes, 1 byte. Now, the size of the game itself isn't only a byte of information. Pick the first Megaman game, for example, it said in the box that it had one Megabit of memory, which equals to 125 KB as aforementioned. But don't worry, that's a common mistake, even Stuttering Craig mistook both.

handgun is a sidearm

author: M Stuart

text: This was actually done as a reference to the old US boxart pictures where Megaman was given a somewhat "westernized" appearance. Due to the 8-bit graphics, the Mega Buster could be misinterpreted as a gun... I think... O.o
